45.heading: 17th Century.
45.title: Une Nuit chez Tennessee
45.author: Autheman.
notes: (Vic Valence ; t. 1)

Summary: Vic Valence is hired to recover diamonds that were once the treasure of a 17th century pirate, then property of Miskito Indians in Nicaragua, and then stolen while being used to buy weapons for the Contras. The thief is an old friend of Valence, who is hiding them on the island of San Severina. Another old friend, the former Miss Tennessee, is hiding the thief.
Genre: Adventure story.

46.heading: 17th Century.
46.title: Pocahontas
46.author: by Laurence Santrey ; illustrated by David Wenzel
notes: Summary: A biography of the seventeenth-century Indian woman whose friendship toward the English settlers at Jamestown was a key factor in making the colony a success.

47.heading: 17th Century.
47.title: The Three Musketeers [sound recording]
47.author: [No author]
notes: 1 sound cassette (33 min.) : analog + 1 booklet (48 p. : ill.)
(Classics Illustrated)
An adaptation of the book by Alexandre Dumas.

Summary: "Set in seventeenth-century England and France, this classic rip-roaring tale tells of valour, intrigue, and love. The three musketeers, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, and their companion, D'Artagnan, fight and love their way through a series of hair-raising adventures."

70.heading: 1775 A.D.
70.title: Espers : Black Magic
70.author: by James D
notes: "Tracy King is possessed by the evil spirit of Aldo Roth. Roth was a powerful necromancer who wanted to usher the world into an age of darkness. Now he's back to finish the job he started in 1775. Roth leads a band of occult assassins out to kill the Espers. Brian Marx has other ideas. Brian was Tracy's boyfriend. He's also a Random Mage. Brian can turn ordinary objects into magical weapons. When Brian teams up with the Espers to stop Roth, things literally go to hell."

notes: México, D.F. : Editorial Pin-Pon, .

103.heading: 1800-1914 A.D.
103.title: "A Timeline, 1800-1914" p. 25-36 in Forging a New Medium : the Comic Strip in the Nineteenth Century
103.author: [No author]

104.heading: 1805 A.D.
104.title: "Prairie Dogs"
104.author: Matthew Wiegle
104.appears_in: p. 177-181 in SPX 2002 : Biographical Comics Issue (Comic Book Legal Defense Fund, 2002).
notes: Story of Lewis and Clark bringing a prairie dog to President Jefferson in 1805.

105.heading: 1810 A.D.
105.title: "Valdivia : la Cureña Humana"
105.author: adaptación literario, Francisco Paz ; ilustraciones de Antonio Gutiérrez ; colaboraron Ignacio Sierra, M
105.appears_in: Monterrugio, Jorge P. Valdés, Antonio Acosta, Gabriel Madrid, miembros de la Sociedad Mexicana de Dibujantes. 32 p. in Biografías Selectas, no. 162 (Dec. 2, 1961).
notes: Takes place during a revolutionary struggle in 1810.

106.heading: 1810-1821 A.D.
106.title: Independencia : México Independiente
106.author: Miguel Angel Gallo.
notes: (Historia de México en Historietas ; t. 2)
On the Wars of Independence, 1810-1821.

107.heading: 1812 Overture.
107.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55 "eighteen-twelve overture"
107.author: [No author]

108.heading: 1814 A.D.
108.title: Ce qu'a vu le Vent de l'Est
108.author: Joëlle Savey.
notes: (Le Postillon ; t. 1)
Historical adventure comic set in France at the end of the First Empire (1814).

109.heading: 1816 A.D.
109.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55 "eighteen-sixteen A.D."
109.author: [No author]

110.heading: 1827 A.D.
110.title: "Merchants of Murder : the Sinister Saga of Burke and Hare"
110.author: W
110.appears_in: Kremer. 8 p. in Crime Must Pay the Penalty, no. 2 (June 1948).
notes: Story about selling corpses for medical research in Edinburgh, in 1827 and 1828.

111.heading: 1830s.
111.title: The Jew of New York
111.author: Ben Katchor.
notes: Summary: A comedy on Jews in 1830s New York, including a scheme to create the first Jewish state on an island near Buffalo.

112.heading: 1830 A.D.
112.title: "Battle of the Beard : Joseph Palmer" 3 p. in True Comics, no. 49
112.author: [No author]
112.series: May/June 1946) ; reprinted in Children's Digest, no. 8
notes: SUMMARY: Joseph Palmer is arrested for defending his beard from ruffians in Fitchburg, Mass., in 1830. His struggle to keep his beard was a victory for civil liberties.

113.heading: 1833 A.D.
113.title: "The First Co-Eds" 2 p. text in Wonder Woman, no. 79
113.author: [No author]
notes: History of women attending college in the U.S., beginning in 1833 at Oberlin College, and describing the beginnings of Mt. Holyoke, Vassar, Smith College, Wellesley, Radcliffe and Barnard.

114.heading: 1836 A.D.
114.title: "The Female Robinson Crusoe" 1 p. text in Wonder Woman, no. 92
114.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The story of a woman ("Juana Maria") left behind on the island of San Nicolas in 1836, her 18 year solitary existence and eventual removal to Santa Barbara (Calif.).

115.heading: 1837 A.D.
115.title: "El 7 de diciembre de 1837 ocurrió una escena extraordinaria en la Cámara de los Comunes inglesa"* 2 p. text in Oklahoma Kid, no. 8
115.author: [No author]
notes: Incipit title.

116.heading: 1849 A.D.
116.title: "Hangtown, California" 1 p. in Real Life Comics, no. 42
116.author: [No author]
notes: "During the '49 gold rush, no man could call his life his own! Not until a crucial hour, when decent miners decided to stand up and fight!"

117.heading: 1850s.
117.title: Children's Stories of the 1850's.
117.author: [No author]

contents.title: Old Mother Mitten and her Funny kitten
The adventures of Mr. Tom Plump
The Funny Book. 1. Funny animal comics. I. [Each story title] II. Series. III. Americana Review. IV. Huestis & Cozans. k. 1850s. Call no.: PN6726.C475 1970z

notes: Scotia, N.Y. : Americana Review, 197-?
(Long ago books)
Reprints of stories published by Huestis & Cozans in the 1850's.

118.heading: 1857 A.D.
118.title: "Pioneer Road Builder" 1 p. in Real Life Comics, no. 57
118.author: [No author]
notes: Story of John Mullan and a road from Missouri to Washington state, authorized in 1857.

119.heading: 1860 A.D.
119.title: "The Man They Couldn't Hang!"
119.author: research, George Di Caprio ; art, Warren Greenwood
notes: About an execution for the crime of suicide, in London in 1860.

120.heading: 1860 A.D.
120.title: "Yo Dome a Abilene" 1 p. in Kid Montana, no. 4
120.author: [No author]
notes: Illustrated fact feature about lawman Tom Smith in Abilene Texas, in 1860.

121.heading: 1861 A.D.
121.title: "Henry Plummer, Virginia City Renegade" 7 p. in Crime Must Pay the Penalty, no. 36
121.author: [No author]
notes: Takes place in 1861.

122.title: "1862" 1 p. in Bakersfield Kountry Komics
122.author: [No author]
notes: By Larry Sutherland.

123.heading: 1862 A.D.
123.title: Shiloh : The Devil's Own Day
123.author: Wayne Vansant, writer-artist ; Ethan Krash, writer-editor.
notes: (The Heritage Collection)
Civil war story about the Battle of Shiloh (1862)
Genres: War, historical.

124.heading: 1862 A.D.
124.title: "They Stole a Train" p. 23-29 in True Comics, no. 9
124.author: [No author]
notes: SUMMARY: In 1862 during the American Civil War, Northerners under James Andrews steal a Confederate railroad train called The General. Called the Chatanooga Railroad Expedition.

125.heading: 1862 A.D.
125.title: Walt Disney's The Great Locomotive Chase.
125.author: [No author]
notes: About the Chatanooga Railroad Expedition of 1862, during the Civil War.
Genres: War, historical.

126.heading: 1863 A.D.
126.title: The Horse Soldiers.
126.author: [No author]
notes: (Dell Movie Classic)
(Four Color ; no. 1048)
Based on the film with John Wayne and William Holden.
A Civil War story, about Grierson's Cavalry Raid in 1863.
Genres: War, historical.

127.heading: 1868 A.D.
127.title: "St. Peter Claver" 6 p. in Catholic Comics, v. 1, no. 11
127.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Claver (1580-) was a missionary to slaves, and was declared a saint in 1868. He was proclaimed "patron of all Negro missions of the world" in 1890.

128.heading: 1869 A.D.
128.title: "The First Football Game" p. 50 in True Comics, no. 18
128.author: [No author]
notes: Played between Rutgers and Princeton, 1869.

129.author: Spain
129.appears_in: 10 p. in Anarchy Comics, no. 4 (1987). - About the Paris Commune.

130.heading: 1872 A.D.
130.title: "Frontier Babylon" 1 p. in Real Life Comics, no. 53
130.author: [No author]
notes: About Dodge City, Kansas, in 1872.
Inside back cover.

131.heading: 1874 A.D.
131.title: "Death on the Plains" 1 p. in Real Life Comics, no. 59
131.author: [No author]
notes: About scout Billy Dixon fighting Kiowa Indians on Sept. 10, 1874.

132.heading: 1876 A.D.
132.title: "Female Troubles, 1876, or,
132.author: Sharon N
132.appears_in: Farmer. 1 p. in Wimmen's Comix, no. 6 (1975).

133.heading: 1880s.
133.title: "Parable!"
133.author: J
133.appears_in: DeFuccio & Severin. p. 84-91 in Cartoonist Profiles, no. 39 (Sept. 1978).
notes: Reprint.

Begins: "Afghanistan, the 1880s! At Kandahar, on the British northwest frontier, Sergeant Patrick Tubridy and a correspondent of the London Daily Press stand on the canteen verandah, in the intense summer heat. They regard the mountainous links that form the mighty chain of the Hindu-Kush."

134.heading: 1880 A.D.
134.title: "Yo-Ho-Ho and a Bottle of Blood" 5 p. in Crime Does Not Pay, no. 57
134.author: [No author]
notes: Takes place in May 1880, about a ship named the Gray Gull that was sunk for insurance money.

135.heading: 1881 to 1885 A.D.
135.title: "Across the Plains and Over the Mountains : The Story of the First Railway to Span Canada" p. 15-17 in Treasure Chest of Fun & Fact, v. 18, no. 6
135.author: [No author]
notes: Construction took from 1881 to 1885.

136.heading: 1881 A.D.
136.title: "On This Date in History, 1881"
136.author: by Dan Piraro.
notes: Summary: President Garfield dreams about a cat, and lasagna.

137.heading: 1886 A.D.
137.title: "The First Electrocution : a Gruesome Thing to See!"
137.author: by M
137.appears_in: Golden. 4 p. in Forbidden Knowledge, no. 2 (1978).
notes: About the execution of William Kemmler in the first electric chair, in 1886.

138.heading: 1888-1889 A.D.
138.title: Jack the Ripper : A Journal of the Whitechapel Murders 1888-1889
138.author: adapted by Rick Geary.
notes: (A Treasury of Victorian Murder ; 2)
Includes bibliographical references (p. 3).
Topic: Serial murders.
Genres: Detective, historical.

139.heading: 1890s.
139.title: "A Bicycle Built for You!" 2 p. text in Wonder Woman, no. 68
139.author: [No author]
notes: A short history of bicycling, tying the introduction of the bicycle in the late 1890s in with the movement toward freedom and equality for women.

140.heading: 1890s.
140.title: "The Gay Nineties Nightmare"
140.author: Jack Cole
notes: Data from Lou Mougin.

141.heading: 1890 A.D.
141.title: La Danse des Fantômes
141.author: Yves Swolfs ; Marc-Rénier ; couleurs, Marie-Noëlle Bastin.
notes: (Black Hills 1890 ; 1)
(Collection Grafica)
About the Dakota Indians, the Ghost Dance movement, and the war of 1890.

142.heading: 1890 A.D.
142.title: "St. Peter Claver" 6 p. in Catholic Comics, v. 1, no. 11
142.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Claver (1580-) was a missionary to slaves, and was declared a saint in 1868. He was proclaimed "patron of all Negro missions of the world" in 1890.

143.heading: 1892 A.D.
143.title: The Borden Tragedy : a Memoir of the Infamous Double Murder at Fall River, Mass., 1892
143.author: adapted and illustrated by Rick Geary.
notes: 1 v. : ill., 23 cm.
(A Treasury of Victorian Murder ; 3)
Summary: Lizzie Borden's trial for the Murder of her parents, Abby and Andrew.
Genre: Horror.

144.heading: 1892 A.D.
144.title: "Los Dueños de la Tierra: 1892"
144.author: David Viñas ; dibujos de Enrique Breccia
144.appears_in: p. 20-29 in: La Argentina en Pedazos (Buenos Aires : Ediciones de la Urraca, 1993).

145.heading: 1895 A.D.
145.title: "Women on Wheels" 2 p. text in Wonder Woman, no. 104
145.author: [No author]
notes: History of women and specialized wagons and carriages, from 450 B.C. to 1895 A.D.

146.heading: 1898 A.D.
146.title: "Hero of Manila Bay"
146.author: [No author]
146.series: Admiral George Dewey) 5 p. in Real Life Comics, no. 42
notes: "In a fighting navy, it's great to be a sailor, a swashbuckling tar in a crew of battling daredevils! Not long ago, it was "Bull" Halsey in the Pacific! But in 1898, it was Dewey, at Manila Bay!"

147.heading: 1898 A.D.
147.title: The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. vol. 1, 1898
147.author: Alan Moore, verbal recitations ; Kevin O'Neill, satirical likenesses ; Benedict Dimagmaliw, polychromopticon ; William Oakley, a laugh, a song, and twenty-six letters.
notes: "Originally published in single magazine form as The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, v. 1, no. 1-6."
Statement of responsibility excerpted from t.p. verso.
Adventure story.

148.heading: 1898 A.D.
148.title: "Splendid Possibilities Undreamed-of-Yet: George du Maurier's 1898 Views on Cartooning's Future"
148.author: introduced by Leonard Rifas
148.appears_in: p. 113-115 in The Comics Journal, no. 207 (Sept. 1998).
notes: (Beyond the Grid)
Article reprinted from his book Social Pictorial Satire (Harper & Bros., 1898)

149.heading: 1899 A.D.
149.title: "Mom Parties Like It's 1899"
149.author: Mike Peters.
notes: Summary: Mother Goose is sleeping in her recliner.

150.heading: 1899 A.D.
150.title: "Outlawed Cartoons"
150.author: illustrated by Denis Kitchen
150.appears_in: 1/2 p. text in Corporate Crime, no. 1 (July 1977).
notes: About an 1899 California law against unfriendly cartoons, provoked by the cartoons of Homer Davenport about the Southern Pacific railroad.

151.title: Chronological Index
notes:
Dates and eras in stories, in history, or in the history of comics are listed here beginning with the earliest. Shortcuts down the list:
  • "19th century"; "1800 to 1899 A.D."
  • "20th century"; "1900 to 1999 A.D."
  • "21st century"; "2000 to 2999 A.D."
  • "22nd century"; "2100 to 2199 A.D."
